Comment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Posse_Comitatus_Act  >The Posse Comitatus Act is a United States federal law (18 U.S.C. § 1385, original at 20 Stat. 152) signed on June 18, 1878, by President Rutherford B. Hayes that **limits the powers of the federal government in the use of federal military personnel to enforce domestic policies within the United States.** Congress passed the Act as an amendment to an army appropriation bill following the end of Reconstruction and updated it in 1956, 1981 and 2021.

Comment: Man thinks you build a military like zergrushing in starcraft  **Look, folks, let me tell you—nobody rushes like the Zerg. Nobody.** They’re fast, they’re nasty, and they’re *tremendous* at overwhelming you before you even know what’s happening. Some say it's unfair. I say it’s smart. Very smart. It's what we used to call a *high-energy strategy*.  **Step one**, you build your *Spawning Pool* early. Very early. Maybe the earliest. People are always shocked. “Is that legal?” they ask. *Yes*, totally legal. Beautiful timing. You skip the economy. You don’t wait around building workers like a loser—no, you get aggressive. You say, *“We're gonna win and we’re gonna win fast.”*  Then you pump out **Zerglings. So many Zerglings. Believe me.** You send them across the map like a wave—*an unstoppable force*. The enemy is still building structures, doing “long-term planning.” But guess what? By the time they’re ready, you’re already in their base. You’re already winning. It’s incredible.

Comment: Yeah.  He has HCM, though that shouldn't need surgery within the next 5 years so that isn't a problem.   But he also has an aortic root dilation, ascending aortic aneurysm and aortic valve reflux. We only found out back in November so we don't know how fast that is growing so can't say how long till he would need a major surgery to replace the valve, root and ascending aorta.   That does tend to be something they wait as long as possible since the repair is only good for 15 years or so (and secondary repairs have very high morbidity and mortality).  And my husband is only 39 so we think he is unlikely to need surgery soon but again we don't have enough data to know.   My son is high functioning, and while I have health issues it's stuff like migraines so I could get at least the two of us out if needed (I don't work since I have chronic migraines, like 25 days a month, though it has been improving) but have worked in genetic research for over a decade before I left the workforce so probably could find work.  But obviously I don't want to leave my husband behind, like it would have to be at the point where they were rounding up people to send to camps for me to make that choice.
